name: The Cloister at Sea Island

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed for just 2 nights in the middle of February. Our room was very spacious, nicely decorated. We looked at 2 rooms - one which was an ocean view and another which was a "river" view, and thought the "river" view was nicer due to the light. If it was warmer outside it would have been wonderful to sit out on the balcony reading a book or having a glass of wine.
reviews.title: Some really good moments, some just ok.

reviews.text: We had dinner at 100 Hudson as the Georgian was closed! Dinner was fine, nothing special, and pricy, but service was just passable. For breakfast the food was edible, but service deteriorated even further from the night before. There is a 20% service charge immediately added to your bill, and I don't appreciate having to pay for sub par service.
reviews.title: exquisite!
Great stay
reviews.text: the next night we had dinner at the lodge at Colt and Allison, where both service and the food were fantastic. Again, they automatically added a 20% service charge to the bill. In this case we felt compelled to add to that.

Both evenings we made our way over to the lodge to watch the sunset - they have a bagpiper playing for an hour outside at that time every day, and it is wonderful to sit and look at the surroundings listening to the bag pipes play.
reviews.title: Cloister in trouble?

reviews.text: We had massages at the spa, both of which were good, and the spa facilities were clean and well maintained (although I wish they had other snacks other than packaged health bars - fruit and nuts would have been much better).
reviews.title: Stayed two days and tried to eat at the...

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I booked my stay a couple of months prior to my visit. Our room was not ready at check-in, which I found a little odd given that we arrived around 4:15 in the afternoon. After waiting for about 30 minutes we inquired about how long it would take for the room to be ready, and were told that it would be another 25-30 minutes, which I found unacceptable. The staff showed us another room (turned out to be an upgrade over our original room (but without the view that we reserved), which turned out to be great.
reviews.title: Some inconveniences

reviews.text: When we arrived we had discovered an error (which Sea Island owned as being there mistake) in the booking of spa appointments, which were not found anywhere in their reservation system. The reservation(s) were later found via a piece of paper that was never entered into their system. Unfortunately, my wife and I were there on a busy weekend, and the spa staff had a difficult time finding solutions to the problem. They ultimately were able to accomodate us, but not without our own aggrevation. They did comp a couple of services, but I would much rather have paid for everything, knowing that my reservations were made and in place prior to my arrival.
reviews.title: Nice time, too crowded, better service to members.

reviews.text: The golf at the Seaside course was outstanding. Beautiful golf course. The Retreat course had just undergone their aeration, and the greens were horrible. I was extremeley dissapointed with the fact that the staff either was not or would not tell me that the aeration would be done shortly before my arrival. Had they done that I would have scheduled my play on the other course(s).
reviews.title: A Classic Southern Family Friendly Resort

reviews.text: The food at both the Georgian Room and Colt and Alison was outstanding. Our meal and service at the Georgian Room was memorable.
reviews.title: A beautiful pampering experience that leaves you overjoyed

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The resort is certainly pricey, but worth the treat.
reviews.title: Best. Spa. Evar!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I visit Sea Island every year, as our family has a house on the island. We have never stayed at the Cloister (we would love to), but we always utilize the hotel and beach club while in town.
reviews.title: Heaven on Earth

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Cloister is a stunning hotel. As soon as you walk in the door, you feel as though you've stepped back in time. The staff is wonderful and will go out of their way to make you feel welcome and comfortable. One of our favorite activities at the hotel is Bingo, which is played every Tuesday and Thursday night. Guests are required to dress up - men must wear coats and no flip flops for ladies. It makes for a fabulous evening out!
reviews.title: Beautiful grounds, outstanding service and fabulous hotel suite

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Beach Club is top notch! There are several different pools, including one for adults only. It is really easy to relax completely!
reviews.title: Beautiful property, immaculate grounds, very relaxing!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I stayed at the Cloister at Sea Island for our anniversary. It is a grand resort. The hotel suite was the nicest I have ever been in with lavish furnishings as well as a comfortable bed. We had a separate living room and bedroom; a powder room and a large marble bathroom as well as a separate dressing area. It is across the road from a quiet beach and there are options for lunch and dinner. We enjoyed the spa. There were several weddings the weekend we were there but we never felt in the way or that our service suffered. They do an amazing job making you feel taken care of without being intrusive. I would definitely go back.
reviews.title: Amazing!

reviews.text: My husband and I stayed for a few nights at the Cloister river view room in my last trimestser of pregnancy as a relaxing getaway. My jaw about hit the floor when we drove up and walked in. This place, and the grounds, are absolutely gorgeous!! (And we have traveled around the world and stayed at some really nice places.) The room was huge and I loved the layout of the bathroom with his and hers sinks and a wall-mounted TV in there. The rain shower was great also.
reviews.title: Can't Wait To Go Again!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: After reading a post on here comparing these two properties, I was wondering what my evaluation would be after similarly staying at both back to back. I can whole heartedly agree with the earlier poster that the Inn at Palmetto Bluff is a vastly superior experience to The Cloisters. The Cloister staff, especially the staff in the Georgia Room, was pretentious, condescending, and made us feel like we were putting them out. And this was when the dining room was only about 25% full on an April weekend. You would think if business is that bad, you'd try to treat the few that do show up with a little appreciation.
reviews.title: Cloisters vs Palmetto Bluff....Palmetto Bluff wins again!

reviews.text: We actually stayed at The Lodge and had problems with room service there. Tried to order a pot of coffee in the morning, was told by the concierge that no one was available to take the order, but that someone would be calling back. Never got that return call. And, again, I stress that this place was easily half empty in late April, their high season.
reviews.title: Great golf but underwhelming service

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: By contrast, the staff at the Inn at PB couldn't have been more discreet and responsive. The food in their dining room was very good, although the menu was a little limited. I hope it's a menu that changes fairly frequently bacause one could get tired of it after a few days. And not a hint of snotty-ness. The Cloisters is trying way too hard to prove their superiority to their guests while the Inn at PB has the quiet confidence of knowing what they have and who they are and they don't have to prove a thing to anybody because they can deliver the goods every time. Can't wait to return to the Inn and PB and don't care to ever set eyes on the Cloisters again!
reviews.title: Worth every penny
Sublime, Special- Exceeds all expectations
reviews.text: My husband and I - and three other couples, stayed at the Cloisters April 15-18 as part of the Platimun Golf Package. Our rooms were at the Beach Club and were beautiful and well appointed. We had never visited before but travel often to better resorts where our husbands, who are avid golfers, can play - and they are serious, 36 holes a day golfers (this is their break - they are physicians, a corporate vp, and my husband is a surgeon). The grounds are beautiful. The courses the boys played were magnificent and worthy of PGA tours. The fitness center was lovely - well appointed and there are folks there for any class or tip a person might need. As I said the golf was terrific, however -- the boys were promised a welcome golf gift as part of their package and it never materialized. They were promised a daily forecaddie and that, too, never materialized and they felt bullied into accepting that it wouldn't be available to them. My husband's golf glove and towel, which were attached to his bag, went missing after the first day and there was no apology and no effort made to locate them. The following day another of our party noticed his towel was missing as well and again, no apology and no effort made to recitify the situation. Service in the restaurants (Colt & Alison, the Oak Room and Big George's) was SLOW. The required 20% gratuity which is automatically added to your bill -- whether you serve yourself at the buffet or have full sit down service - was a bit grating to us. We are generous tippers but prefer to use our discretion. Often we leave 25% or more but when we are told what to do we stop right there. My husband had a glass of orange juice one morning prior to golf and couldn't believe the added gratuity. (this was not sit down service either -- simply a grab and go) Housekeeping was very pleasant, but I was dismayed to find the previous room's occupant's undergarments in a dresser drawer -- I gave the items to the maid who was apologetic but it was sloppy. Several in our party expressed have our concern to the staff, but have heard nothing from them - a bit disappointing. Bar service around the pool was lackluster - the service person quickly walked around and unless you were looking for her and could wave her down you were on your own. The pools, though, are beautiful. Overall this is a beautiful resort but they need to brush up a bit. I think next time we'll head to Reynold's Plantation, which ironically was where we were first considering when making these plans -- but I was the one who wanted to visit this property and won out! Wish it had turned out a bit better.

reviews.title: Fabulous getaway
reviews.text: This is a beautiful hotel located in a perfect location.We stayed at the Ocean Villas which is right at the edge and very secluded.The beach on the right side of the building is totally secluded and is great for long walks. Make sure to take some bug spray if you are going here in summer time. I would strongly suggest to have at least one dinner at the Georgian Room (closed on Sunday and Monday).

reviews.title: Very Upscale experience, but break out your wallet
reviews.text: Wow, this place deserves all the acolades, but it is very expensive. They had a library and game room at The Cloister which children enjoyed. Breakfast buffet was good ($21/pp); Dinner buffet was not great and cost $35/pp. I asked to waive the resort fee since it was raining and cold and we literally could not use the pools and amenities. Make sure to bring nice clothes and collared shirts for the men. I would not recommend this hotel if you have young children, unless you are wealthy. Would definitely come here for a weekend as a couple, maybe an anniversary. I was stressed that my kids would act up in such a classy 5 star environment (and they are good kids).

reviews.title: Cloister compared to Inn at Palmetto Bluff
reviews.text: on my way home from visiting family i thought i'd treat myself to a night at the Inn at Palmetto Bluff and then a night at the Cloister, as they are only 2 hours apart. on all criteria Palmetto Bluff is a better resort. Just one example of the detail that separates the two. At PB they welcome you with a note, a full bottle of wine and a bag of spicy pecans. at the cloister you get a note at turn down service. I did like the design of the cloister but didn't care for the property layout. i also thought the pool was ugly while at PM the pool overlooks the lagoon and takes your breath away. i also hated the dining options at the cloister. i'm not one for fine dining so i lunch at the river house bar and then wanted to eat there again for dinner but it was too crowded. went over to big georges and it was just a low rent looking restaurant. i sat at the bar and there were 9 teenagers at the bar drinking hot coco. What?? if you have a choice, go with Palmetto Bluff.

reviews.title: gorgeous setting,overpriced,rude staff ,soso food
reviews.text: My family will not return to the Cloister.The rudeness by the staff is unlike any luxury hotel,

reviews.title: Driving an old car made me unwelcome to stay.
reviews.text: Ihave visited.

reviews.title: Wonderful Vacation with Family
reviews.text: We arrived in an older model, Mercury sedan. The guard at the gate told me we were at the wrong hotel before asking my name to see if we had reservations. After a long ordeal that never included an apology, we were shown our room. The room was lovely. The bed was supremely comfortable. The shower was roomy enough for two and the soaking tub was great. Sadly, the horrible customer service ruined out stay.

The Cloister experience is no question high-end. Restaurants are 5 star and amazing. Service is attentive. Facilities are all beautiful. And they cater well to families and couples alike. Be prepared to spend a lot of money on everything you do, this is not a low cost vacation. But the experience was unique and fun, especially the can't-miss bingo night -- the most unexpected, best evening we had there for all ages in our group (really, I'm not kidding).
reviews.title: Luxurious accommodations and amenities plus unique activities - definitely a splurge but a one-of-a-kind experience.

reviews.text: The place was built for KINGS and we were treated like royalty! Clean as a whistle and every detail thought of...someone was always around to help if you had questions. The grounds were gorgeous and the rooms were amazing!
reviews.title: Absolutely AMAZING-When can I return??

reviews.text: We are looking forward to returning on our own and relaxing even more!
reviews.title: A New Measure of Excellence

reviews.text: The SPA was to die for!
reviews.title: Wonderful experience

reviews.text: We spent a week at The Cloiser recently and, based upon what we heard and read of the Cloiser, went with a very high level of expectation. As high as our expectations were, they were overwhelmingly exceeded!! The facilities and grounds are immaculate and inviting, the rooms are spacious and inviting, the staff is incredible to a fault, the dining was great at every restaurant and the activities we participated in turned out perfectly. We "endured" a week of perfect southern hospitality, and the resort, although very formal in appearance, was incredibly comfortable. The Cloister is our new "standard" of excellence ... thanks to all staff at the Cloister for a job perfectly done!!
reviews.title: outstanding
